content.text: Chart Module Demo
Here we demonstrate the use of the Apogee Chart.js Module.
Chart Examples
In this workspace we show several examples of using the chart module. The following pages, which you can access in the left (tree) panel, each show examples:
barChartPage
- This example shows a bar chart. Here we provide the input data as a data map to give the Y values.
lineCategoryPlotPage
- This example shows a line chart with category data. Here we provide the input data in data arrays along with accessor functions.
xyPlotPage
- This example shows an line chart as an XY plot plot. We provide our values and separate X and Y value arrays.
chartsWithConfigJsonPage
- This example shows how to use a config JSON rather than using the form to configure the chart.
We do not include examples of all possible combinations of input data, but hopefully you can piece together other scenarios from these examples.
Adding the Chart.js Cell to Your Workspace
To use the Chart.js cell you must add the Chart.js Web Module to your workspace. To see the URL of the web module do the following:
In the left (tree) panel and click on the menu (three dots) for the entry "Chart.js Module" in this workspace, under "Web Modules", which is under "Libraries".
From the menu, click on "Update Web Module"
In the dialog box, you can see the URL for the module.
Copy this and add it to the Web Modules in your workspace. Do this by selecting "Add ES Web Module" from the "Web Modules" entry in your workspace.
XY Plot, Using Separate X and Y Arrays

Here we will graph data where we plot each point according to X and Y numeric coordinates. To provide the data for the chart in this example, the X and Y values are in separate arrays. (It is also possible to extract both X and Y values from a single array.)
Data: Sine and Cosine Waves
Here we generate some date: a series of angle values, and then
sin()
and cos() of each angle.
The sin() of each angle:
The code() of each angle:
Plots
For numeric X data we can use either a line chart or a scatter chart. We will show a line chart.
Chart 1
For our line chart we selected
Coordinate Type
to be
XY Plot
. We want to control the numeric position of each point on both the X and Y axes.
We added two data series. We selected the
Data Format
option
X Array and Y Array
We have left the options
X Accessor
and
Y Accessor

blank. The elements in the arrays are the values we want to plot. If the elements were a more complex structure, we would use the accessor to pull out the X and Y values from these elements. Other examples demonstrate the use of these.
We have also added a label for each series under
Series Options
We have used all the default
Chart Options
Chart 2
Here is a second chart. It is identical to the first except we have modified one
Chart Option
. We have turned off
Line Tension
. By default the line tension is set to a non-zero value, which smooths the plotted lines.
Bar Chart with a Data Map
Here we look at plotting the following data:
X Data is in
categories
, which means the X axis has a set of discrete values. In this case the discrete values are endpoints on a web server. They could also be something like calendar dates.
Y Values are numbers
The data is given a
map
object, or a normal JSON object.. This means we have a set of keys (the endpoint names) and the values associated with each.
Note that we have other options for how the data is specified. It can be in an array of values, for example.
Data: Endpoint Counts Map
This is endpoint request counts from a web server.
Plots
We can do either a bar or line chart were we have Y values plotted against discrete categories. We choose a bar chart here.
Bar Chart
Here we added a single
Data Series
and we use the
Data Map
data format, since our data is in the form of a map.
Our
Data Map
is set as
endpointCounts
. This field in the form is a javascript expression, so we can write javscript we want. Typically you will write the name of a cell which contains the data, which is in turn a javascript variable.
We leave a few optional fields blank:
X Category Array
- These are the columns in the bar chart. For
Data Map

input we can leave this blank because the columns are already specified in the data. (On the other hand we can also include this array, in which case the chart will show exactly the categories specified in the X category array, in that order)
X Category Array Accessor
- This is blank because we did not enter an
X Category Array
. If we did enter this field, we still may or may not need an accessor. See other examples for it's use.
Y Accessor

- This is a function to read data from our data map. We would use this if the values in the map were a structure rather than the simple numbers we want to plot. But we have no need for it here. The accessors are very helpful and are illustrated in other examples.
We also added a label to the data series, in the
Series Options
We used all the default values for the
Chart Options
Line Chart
We can also create a line chart with this data.

The line chart looks just like the bar chart with one exception. Line charts supports two coordinate types, corresponding to discreet X values like we have here, or XY plots, where points are plotted according to their X and Y value. So for line charts the form has an additional field where you specify which type of data you have. We chose
Coordinates Type
to be
Y Values in discrete category
Line Chart with a Data Array and Accessors
Here we look at plotting the following data:
X Data is in
categories
, which means the X axis has a set of discrete values. In this case the discrete values are age in years.
Y Values are numbers
The data is given as an array of data. The array contains structs rather than simple values. In chart this we will demonstrate the use of
accessors
Data: Population Statistics
This is an array of objects containing population data.
Plots
Here we chart our population data.
Here we select a line chart with category data, as opposed to an XY plot.
In this example we use
accessors
. This is a function that converts from our input data array to the appropriate values.
We add two data series, one for males and one for females. we selected
Data Array
for the format since we have an array of data: our series data comes from an array rather than a map/JSON Object.
In this example, our array of data,
popData1980
, is an array of structs, or JSON Objects that has all of our input values -  the male and female counts and the category (age) we are plotting against. To read each specific values, we provide
accessor functions
To be more specific, internally the array of data is created as follows:
categoryArray = popData1980.map(element => element.age)
malesYArray = popData1980.map(element => element.males)
femalesYArray = popData1980.map(element => element.females)
In the accessor field we provided the appropriate functions. in this example we typed in a
javascript arrow function
. We could also have defined a function cell and typed in the name of the function cell for that field.

Note that we don't need accessors. We could instead define three new cells that contain an array of ages, an array of male population counts and an array of female population counts. However, if you are comfortable with accessors, they can be convenient.
We have also added a label for each series under
Series Options
We also customized one of the
Chart Options
. We chose not to show the points, to make the graph cleaner.
Charts Using the Config Option

When creating a chart, using the form to configure the chart is the easiest way to do it. However, sometimes this isn't what you want to do. One example is when you want to programmatically change the number of dat series included on the chart. You can not do this if you are using the form.
When you use the
config JSON
option, you provide a single JSON object that has all the chart configuration in it. There are two options for the format of this JSON:
Apogee Format
- This is a custom format that very closely reflects the form. It may be easy to use because the content is very similar to the form.
Chart.js Format

- This is the native format for Chart.js, the library used to construct these charts. This provides complete flexibility and access to all the chart features. To create it you can use the documentation provided by Chart.js.
We will not document these wo formats here, but we will show a trick to help you use these.
Look at the formula of the cell below. We return the
value
of an existing chart using form input on another page. It contains a number of fields inside it:
formData - This is the data that is placed in the form.
formResult - This is the form data after any expressions have been executed. As we see below, this contains the Apogee Format config JSON.
data - This is the raw config file that is passed to the chart library, as converted from the form result. This is the Chart.js Format config JSON.
So, this means you can create a chart using the form and extract the chart config that you want. Then you can modify it, such as programmatically creating as many data series as you want.
Apogee Format Config JSON
The formula below shows how we pull the Apogee format config JSON from the existing chart value above.
Here we plug that config into the chart below and reproduce the chart on the other page.
Chart.js Format Config JSON
The formula below shows how we pull the Chart.js format config JSON from the existing chart value above.
Here we plug that config into the chart below and reproduce the chart on the other page.
Create Your Own Chart.js Format Config JSON
The Chart.js web site is at the following URL:
https://www.chartjs.org/
You can use the documentation there and create your own config file.
In the cell below, I copied an example chart config file from that web site. I then use it in the chart below.
Here is the chart with the chart config copied from the Chart.js website.
